name: Tunnel View
description: One of the best viewpoints in Yosemite requiring no hiking, providing iconic views of the valley and its granite peaks.
tips: Expect the viewpoint to be busy throughout the day
Arrive at least 30 minutes before sunrise or sunset
A 35mm lens is effective for capturing the perspective of the valley

name: Glacier Point
description: An extremely accessible spot that provides a wide panorama and a direct view of Half Dome from the historic hut.
tips: Walk to the little hut for the most framed and famous view
Prepare for crowds even at sunrise
Find unique rock formations along the path to use as foreground

name: Taft Point
description: Known for its dramatic and scary rock edges that overlook the valley floor from a high elevation.
tips: Plan for a 2.3-mile return hike to reach the point
Be extremely careful near the rock edges as drop-offs are steep and unguarded
Bring a headlamp for the hike back through the woods in the dark

name: Sentinel Bridge
description: Famous for its perfect reflection of Half Dome in the Merced River.
tips: Position your subject in the meadow with the falls directly behind them
Wide-angle lenses work well here to capture the scale of the falls

name: Yosemite Falls (Cook Meadow)
description: A scenic boardwalk loop in Yosemite Valley offering flat perspectives of the meadows and cliffs with the falls in the background.
tips: Parking is available right next to the boardwalk for quick access
Great for walking shots or capturing the valley floor architecture

name: Mirror Lake
description: A popular spot for capturing the still reflections of the surrounding granite walls in the water.
tips: Visit in late Spring or early Summer when the lake is actually full of water
The water is often most still in the early morning

name: Vernal Falls
description: One of the park's most iconic waterfalls, famous for its powerful flow and mist along the Mist Trail.
tips: Expect to get wet from the mist; protect your camera gear with a cover
Look for rainbows created by the sun hitting the mist in the afternoon

name: Superintendentâ€™s Bridge
description: A bridge over the Merced River that serves as both a swimming hole and a great spot for action photography.
tips: Use a fast shutter speed to capture people jumping into the water
Perfect spot for mid-day lifestyle and swimming shots

name: Eagle Peak
description: A high vantage point offering sweeping panoramic views across Yosemite National Park and Upper Yosemite Fall.
tips: This location requires a significant hike, so plan your time accordingly
Bring plenty of snacks and water for the trek
